practitioner_domains.domain_description: Clinical cancer treatment and management focusing on all solid tumors
practitioner_domains.specialization_notes: Half of clinical time spent in actual cancer treatment, with subspecialty interest in breast cancer

practitioner_domains.domain_description: Clinic focused on catching cancer early across all solid tumor types
practitioner_domains.specialization_notes: Utilizes blood work, imaging, physical assessments and surveys for early cancer detection

practitioner_domains.domain_description: Genetic assessment and counseling for hereditary cancer risk
practitioner_domains.specialization_notes: Focuses on inherited cancer risk assessment and genetic testing recommendations

constructs_mentioned.construct_description: Assessment of lifetime and 10-year probability of developing breast cancer
constructs_mentioned.why_important: Primary focus for high-risk breast cancer program and early intervention strategies
constructs_mentioned.how_assessed: Genetic cancer risk assessment surveys, Tyrer-Cuzick calculator, Gail model, imaging, genetics testing

constructs_mentioned.construct_description: Categorization of breast tissue density (A, B, C, D categories) affecting cancer detection
constructs_mentioned.why_important: Dense tissue makes cancer harder to detect and requires supplemental imaging
constructs_mentioned.how_assessed: Automated software analysis of mammogram images with radiologist confirmation

constructs_mentioned.construct_description: Assessment of whether mammogram captured all breast tissue with adequate positioning
constructs_mentioned.why_important: Poor quality images may miss cancer due to incomplete tissue capture
constructs_mentioned.how_assessed: Third-party software analysis (e.g., Densitas) to evaluate image acquisition quality

constructs_mentioned.construct_description: Comprehensive assessment of cancer incidence in first, second, and third degree relatives
constructs_mentioned.why_important: Critical for determining genetic testing eligibility and inherited cancer risk
constructs_mentioned.how_assessed: Detailed pedigree analysis including cancer types, ages of diagnosis, and relationship mapping

constructs_mentioned.construct_description: Assessment of inherited genetic mutations that increase cancer susceptibility
constructs_mentioned.why_important: Identifies high-penetrance mutations requiring intensive screening and prevention strategies
constructs_mentioned.how_assessed: NCCN guidelines-based survey followed by DNA testing via blood or saliva

constructs_mentioned.construct_description: Height and weight-based calculation used in cancer risk assessment
constructs_mentioned.why_important: Modifiable risk factor that influences breast cancer risk calculations
constructs_mentioned.how_assessed: Height and weight measurements incorporated into Tyrer-Cuzick risk calculator

health_performance_factors.description: Alcohol intake as a modifiable risk factor for breast cancer through metabolic pathways
health_performance_factors.measurement_approach: Social history assessment and lifestyle modification counseling

health_performance_factors.description: Lean muscle mass, body fat percentage, and fat distribution affecting cancer risk
health_performance_factors.measurement_approach: Assessment beyond BMI focusing on visceral adipose tissue and organ function impact

health_performance_factors.description: Medical and natural estrogen exposure affecting breast cancer risk
health_performance_factors.measurement_approach: Gynecologic history including births, hormonal medications, menstrual history

health_performance_factors.description: Occupational and environmental risk factors including radiation exposure
health_performance_factors.measurement_approach: Comprehensive social and occupational history assessment

health_performance_factors.description: Sleep patterns affecting overall health and cancer risk through lifestyle medicine pillars
health_performance_factors.measurement_approach: Part of comprehensive lifestyle assessment for risk modification

health_performance_factors.description: Stress levels and management as part of lifestyle medicine approach to cancer prevention
health_performance_factors.measurement_approach: Assessment within lifestyle medicine pillars framework

health_performance_factors.description: Social connections and support systems affecting overall health outcomes
health_performance_factors.measurement_approach: Social history assessment including marital status and family support

assessments.assessment_description: A questionnaire that identifies personal history and family history factors to determine lifetime and 10-year risk of developing cancer

administration_details.where_performed: Home/clinic via mobile phone or QR code
administration_details.preparation_required: Patient needs family history information up to third degree relatives

key_steps: Patient receives link or QR code 5 days before appointment
System uses conditional logic guided questionnaire
Results go to dashboard for clinician review
Clinician verifies answers and fills gaps when patient arrives
coaching_cues: Include cancer types and ages of diagnosis for relatives
common_mistakes: Patients skip questions they don't understand
Inaccurate answers due to lack of family history knowledge
Not knowing specific pathology results from previous biopsies
quality_controls: Clinician verification of answers at appointment
Ability to modify and recalculate results
Conditional logic to guide appropriate questions

assessments.assessment_description: Systematic collection of patient's medical background including present illness, personal medical history, medications, allergies, surgeries, family history, social history, and gynecologic history

administration_details.preparation_required: Patient should gather medical records and family history

key_steps: History of present illness and chief complaint
Personal medical history (diagnoses, medications, allergies, surgeries)
Family history up to third degree relatives with cancer types and ages
Social history (smoking, environmental exposures, employment, social support)
Gynecologic history (births, hormonal exposure, miscarriages, previous biopsies)
coaching_cues: Generate detailed pedigree for family history
Document cancer incidence by age and type
quality_controls: Systematic review of all history components

assessments.assessment_description: Comprehensive physical examination of the body utilizing various clinical tools

key_steps: Use of various clinical examination tools

assessments.assessment_description: 14-point head-to-toe questionnaire that identifies symptoms across all body systems to detect hidden issues that may be related to diagnosis

key_steps: Identify any symptoms patient may have
coaching_cues: Ask about symptoms in all body systems
Don't assume symptoms are unrelated to cancer risk
common_mistakes: Patients may not report symptoms they think are unrelated
quality_controls: Documentation of all positive and negative findings

assessments.assessment_description: X-ray imaging of the breast to identify abnormal patterns, distortions, lesions, or suspicions of cancer, available in 2D and 3D (tomosynthesis) formats

administration_details.frequency: Annual for screening, or as recommended based on risk

key_steps: AI/CAD software analysis for pattern recognition
Automated density categorization (A, B, C, D)
Comparison with prior images if available
Generation of medical report and patient letter
coaching_cues: Ensure proper breast positioning in paddles
Use highest quality equipment available (3D preferred)
Verify prior images are available for comparison
common_mistakes: Inadequate breast positioning leading to incomplete tissue capture
Poor image quality due to patient movement
quality_controls: Use certified imaging centers with quality equipment
Automated density assessment with radiologist verification
Quality assurance through positioning assessment software

assessments.assessment_description: Whole breast ultrasound imaging used as supplemental screening, particularly for women with dense breast tissue or elevated risk

administration_details.frequency: Recommended for dense breasts (Category C/D) or intermediate risk (Tyrer-Cusk 15-20%)

assessments.assessment_description: High-resolution magnetic resonance imaging of both breasts used for high-risk women to detect cancers that may be missed by mammography and ultrasound

quality_controls: Strict patient selection criteria (>20% lifetime risk)

assessments.assessment_description: DNA analysis via blood or saliva to identify hereditary cancer mutations such as BRCA1, BRCA2, and other cancer-associated genes

administration_details.where_performed: Lab/clinic for sample collection, third-party lab for analysis
administration_details.duration: Brief sample collection, results in 1-2 weeks
administration_details.frequency: One-time test, family cascade testing may follow

key_steps: Laboratory analysis by specialized genetics lab
Family cascade testing recommendations if positive
coaching_cues: Ensure appropriate patient selection based on NCCN criteria
common_mistakes: Inadequate family history to justify testing
quality_controls: Follow NCCN guidelines for testing criteria

assessments.assessment_description: Pan-cancer blood test for early detection of multiple solid tumor types, though noted as having limited sensitivity and specificity for breast cancer

administration_details.frequency: Not routinely recommended for breast cancer screening

coaching_cues: Understand limitations for breast cancer detection
Not recommended as primary screening tool
common_mistakes: Using as replacement for standard screening
quality_controls: Use only as adjunct to standard screening

interventions.intervention_description: Whole breast ultrasound performed in addition to mammography for women with dense breast tissue or intermediate breast cancer risk
interventions.purpose: To detect cancers that mammography may miss in dense breast tissue and provide more comprehensive breast screening

implementation_specifics.delivery_method: Performed at breast imaging center by trained technicians
implementation_specifics.monitoring_approach: Results reviewed by radiologist and integrated with mammography findings
implementation_specifics.adjustment_criteria: Based on breast density category C or D, or Tyra-Cusk score 15-20%

resource_requirements.time_commitment: Additional imaging time during screening visit

interventions.intervention_description: High-resolution magnetic resonance imaging of both breasts for high-risk women
interventions.purpose: Enhanced early detection for women at high risk of breast cancer

implementation_specifics.delivery_method: Performed at imaging center with MRI capability
implementation_specifics.monitoring_approach: Radiologist interpretation with comparison to prior studies
implementation_specifics.adjustment_criteria: Recommended for Tyra-Cusk score greater than 20%

interventions.intervention_description: Anti-estrogen medication to reduce breast cancer risk in high-risk women
interventions.purpose: Reduce likelihood of developing breast cancer by 50% in high-risk women

implementation_specifics.monitoring_approach: Regular follow-up visits to monitor side effects and compliance
implementation_specifics.adjustment_criteria: Recommended for Gail score greater than 1.66% 10-year risk

interventions.intervention_description: DNA analysis to identify hereditary cancer risk mutations
interventions.purpose: Identify inherited genetic mutations that increase cancer risk for patient and family members

implementation_specifics.delivery_method: Blood draw or saliva collection sent to specialized laboratory
implementation_specifics.monitoring_approach: Results reviewed by genetic counselor and physician
implementation_specifics.adjustment_criteria: Recommended based on NCCN guidelines and family history

resource_requirements.time_commitment: Single collection appointment plus counseling sessions

interventions.intervention_description: Individualized imaging schedule based on personal risk factors
interventions.purpose: Provide tailored screening frequency and modalities based on individual risk profile

dosage_details.frequency: Varies based on risk level (6 months to annually)
dosage_details.progression: Adjusted based on changing risk factors

implementation_specifics.monitoring_approach: Regular risk reassessment and protocol adjustment
implementation_specifics.adjustment_criteria: Based on comprehensive risk assessment including imaging, family history, and genetics

resource_requirements.expertise_required: Multidisciplinary team including radiologists and risk assessment specialists

interventions.intervention_description: Comprehensive lifestyle modification program targeting nutrition, exercise, sleep, stress management, social connection, and avoiding risky behaviors
interventions.purpose: Reduce breast cancer risk through modifiable lifestyle factors and improve overall health

dosage_details.intensity: Individualized based on current fitness and health status
dosage_details.progression: Gradual implementation and advancement of healthy behaviors

implementation_specifics.delivery_method: Multidisciplinary team approach with nutrition, exercise, and behavioral specialists
implementation_specifics.monitoring_approach: Regular assessment of lifestyle metrics and risk factors
implementation_specifics.adjustment_criteria: Based on individual response and changing risk profile

resource_requirements.time_commitment: Daily lifestyle practices with periodic coaching sessions
resource_requirements.expertise_required: Lifestyle medicine specialists, nutritionists, exercise physiologists

interventions.intervention_description: Educational intervention to reduce alcohol consumption as part of breast cancer risk reduction
interventions.purpose: Reduce breast cancer risk by eliminating liquid sugar intake and improving body composition

dosage_details.intensity: Comprehensive education on alcohol-cancer risk relationship
dosage_details.volume: Complete alcohol avoidance or significant reduction
dosage_details.progression: Gradual reduction with sustained abstinence or minimal consumption

implementation_specifics.adjustment_criteria: Based on individual risk factors and response to intervention

resource_requirements.time_commitment: Initial education sessions plus ongoing support
resource_requirements.expertise_required: Healthcare providers trained in lifestyle counseling

interventions.intervention_description: Systematic approach to inform and screen family members based on genetic test results
interventions.purpose: Identify and prevent cancer in DNA relatives through cascade screening

dosage_details.duration: Immediate family notification with long-term screening
dosage_details.intensity: Comprehensive genetic counseling and risk communication
dosage_details.volume: All relevant family members up to third-degree relatives
dosage_details.progression: Initial notification followed by individual risk assessment for each family member

implementation_specifics.monitoring_approach: Tracking of family member screening uptake
implementation_specifics.adjustment_criteria: Based on genetic test results and family pedigree analysis

resource_requirements.time_commitment: Initial counseling sessions plus family coordination time

construct_relationships.relationship_description: Higher breast density makes it harder to see through tissue, reducing mammogram effectiveness
construct_relationships.evidence_mentioned: Dense breasts are tightly packed and harder to see through, making mammogram alone incomplete

construct_relationships.relationship_description: Changes in BMI directly affect breast cancer risk calculations
construct_relationships.evidence_mentioned: If BMI goes down, risk goes down - used in Tyrer-Cuzick risk calculation

construct_relationships.relationship_description: Family history patterns indicate potential inherited genetic mutations
construct_relationships.evidence_mentioned: Family history of cancer in relatives up to third degree informs genetic risk assessment

construct_relationships.relationship_description: Genetic mutations dramatically increase breast cancer risk
construct_relationships.evidence_mentioned: BRCA2 increases lifetime risk from 12.5% to 60-80%

construct_relationships.relationship_description: Breast density changes with hormonal status and affects risk assessment
construct_relationships.evidence_mentioned: Breast density changes as hormonal status changes from premenopausal to postmenopausal

intervention_construct_links.mechanism_of_action: Provides additional imaging modality to see through dense breast tissue that mammogram may miss
intervention_construct_links.timeline_expectations: Immediate - performed at time of mammogram or shortly after

intervention_construct_links.mechanism_of_action: High-resolution imaging for high-risk patients to detect cancers mammogram may miss
intervention_construct_links.timeline_expectations: 6 months interval from mammogram for high-risk patients

intervention_construct_links.mechanism_of_action: Anti-estrogen medication blocks estrogen receptors to reduce cancer development
intervention_construct_links.timeline_expectations: 5 years of treatment for sustained risk reduction

intervention_construct_links.mechanism_of_action: Addresses modifiable risk factors through nutrition, exercise, sleep, stress management
intervention_construct_links.timeline_expectations: Continuous lifestyle changes with gradual risk improvement

intervention_construct_links.mechanism_of_action: Tailored imaging cadence based on individual risk assessment
intervention_construct_links.timeline_expectations: Ongoing - adjusted screening intervals based on risk

intervention_construct_links.mechanism_of_action: Reduces liquid sugar intake and metabolic cancer drivers
intervention_construct_links.timeline_expectations: Immediate behavioral changes with gradual metabolic improvements

assessment_intervention_connections.connection_description: Survey results determine if patient qualifies for genetic testing based on NCCN guidelines
Breast density category C or D on mammogram triggers recommendation for ultrasound
Tyrer-Cuzick score >20% from history triggers MRI recommendation
Gail score >1.66% 10-year risk qualifies patient for chemoprevention consideration
BMI and body composition findings inform lifestyle intervention recommendations
Positive genetic results trigger family member risk assessment and communication
Blood test results may inform screening intensity, though limited utility in breast cancer

mentioned_advantages: does both cancer risk assessment and genetics risk assessment all in one survey tool

mentioned_limitations: no longer available under that name

mentioned_advantages: determines if image was acquired with quality

mentioned_limitations: not specific enough for breast cancer
lousy screening test for premenopausal women

metrics.normal_ranges: Greater than 20% = high risk, 15-20% = intermediate risk, less than 15% = average risk
metrics.interpretation_notes: Threshold of 20% is about twice the average population risk
metrics.reliability_notes: Completely flawed because lifetime risk for 70-year-old vs 40-year-old has different time horizons

metrics.interpretation_notes: Not as actionable as lifetime risk

metrics.normal_ranges: Greater than 1.66% per year qualifies for chemoprevention
metrics.interpretation_notes: Used to determine eligibility for tamoxifen chemoprevention

metrics.normal_ranges: A and B = non-dense, C = heterogeneously dense, D = extremely dense
metrics.interpretation_notes: C or D density requires supplemental ultrasound imaging
metrics.reliability_notes: Automated software with radiologist final approval

metrics.interpretation_notes: Circles suspicious areas with worry ratings
metrics.reliability_notes: Improved accuracy with AI pattern recognition

metrics.interpretation_notes: Rules engine based on family history criteria
metrics.reliability_notes: Too complicated for clinicians and patients to understand

metrics.interpretation_notes: Used in Tyrer-Cuzick calculation, inadequate measure
metrics.reliability_notes: Inadequate score, doesn't reflect body composition

client_goals.goal_description: Early detection of breast cancer to catch cancer at stage 0, 1, or 2
client_goals.timeline: Ongoing screening with risk-stratified intervals (annual, 6-month, or more frequent)
client_goals.priority_level: High - early detection equals less treatment, toxicity, and cost

client_goals.goal_description: Reduce breast cancer risk through lifestyle modifications
client_goals.timeline: Continuous - risk is dynamic and modifiable

client_goals.goal_description: Identify hereditary cancer risk in patient and family members
client_goals.priority_level: Critical for BRCA and other high-penetrance mutations

constraints_preferences.description: Less than half of breast imaging centers perform comprehensive risk assessment
constraints_preferences.impact_on_assessment: Many women receive incomplete screening without risk stratification
constraints_preferences.impact_on_intervention: Limits ability to provide precision screening recommendations
workaround_strategies: Seek certified centers with 3D mammography and risk assessment programs

constraints_preferences.description: Complex surveys are difficult to administer during clinical visits
constraints_preferences.impact_on_assessment: 50% of patients don't complete pre-visit surveys
constraints_preferences.impact_on_intervention: Incomplete risk assessment leads to suboptimal screening recommendations

constraints_preferences.description: Tyra-Cusk model excludes males and patients with prior breast cancer
constraints_preferences.impact_on_assessment: Cannot assess lifetime risk in these populations
constraints_preferences.impact_on_intervention: Must rely on genetic testing and alternative risk models

constraints_preferences.description: Availability of 3D mammography and AI-assisted detection varies by center
constraints_preferences.impact_on_assessment: 2D mammograms miss cancers that 3D would detect
constraints_preferences.impact_on_intervention: Suboptimal screening quality affects early detection
workaround_strategies: Ensure prior imaging availability for comparison

moderating_factors.description: Patients don't understand breast density categories, biopsy results, or family history significance
moderating_factors.what_it_affects: Assessment accuracy - patients skip questions or answer incorrectly
moderating_factors.management_approach: Clinical staff verification, education, and survey completion assistance

moderating_factors.description: Patients increasingly don't know detailed family cancer history, especially third-degree relatives
moderating_factors.what_it_affects: Risk assessment accuracy for both lifetime risk and genetic testing qualification
moderating_factors.management_approach: Encourage family communication, use available information, consider genetic testing with incomplete history

moderating_factors.description: Mammogram interpretation requires comparison with previous images
moderating_factors.what_it_affects: Assessment accuracy - single image sets are like 'one chapter in a multi-chapter book'
moderating_factors.management_approach: Ensure centers obtain prior imaging, patient brings records, establish imaging home base

moderating_factors.description: Larger, more deformable breasts are harder to position consistently in mammography
moderating_factors.what_it_affects: Mammogram quality and cancer detection sensitivity
moderating_factors.management_approach: Use mammogram quality assessment tools, experienced technicians, consider supplemental imaging

individual_differences.assessment_implications: Breast density changes with hormonal status - postmenopausal women typically have less dense breasts
individual_differences.intervention_implications: Risk is dynamic and screening recommendations may change over time

individual_differences.assessment_implications: Dense breasts (C/D) make mammogram interpretation more difficult
individual_differences.intervention_implications: Dense breasts require supplemental ultrasound imaging regardless of other risk factors

individual_differences.assessment_implications: BMI affects breast cancer risk calculation in Tyra-Cusk model
individual_differences.intervention_implications: BMI reduction can lower risk scores and is a modifiable intervention target

individual_differences.assessment_implications: BRCA mutations increase lifetime risk from 12.5% to 60-80%
individual_differences.intervention_implications: Completely changes screening algorithm - more frequent imaging, different intervals, cascade family testing

individual_differences.assessment_implications: Males represent 1% of breast cancers but are excluded from standard risk models
individual_differences.intervention_implications: Must rely on genetic testing and family history rather than standard risk calculators

processed_files.file_name: Ontology Knowledge Gathering Interview - Mollie – 2025_07_24 17_13 BST – Notes by Gemini.txt

practitioner_domains.domain_description: Six areas of lifestyle: nutrition, physical activity, sleep, stress reduction/management, substance use reduction, and positive social connection. Leverages these elements to prevent disease and treat existing conditions.
practitioner_domains.specialization_notes: Primary area of expertise focusing on optimal health and functioning through evidence-based lifestyle interventions

practitioner_domains.domain_description: Blood glucose management across the spectrum of insulin resistance, from normal glycemic control to impaired glucose tolerance, pre-diabetes, type 2 diabetes, and end-stage diabetes requiring insulin
practitioner_domains.specialization_notes: Also referred to as 'blood glucose management' - encompasses the full spectrum of insulin resistance conditions

practitioner_domains.domain_description: Prevention and treatment of chronic conditions using both conventional western medicine and lifestyle interventions
practitioner_domains.specialization_notes: Blends conventional western medicine with lifestyle medicine approaches

practitioner_domains.domain_description: Management of cardiovascular and metabolic conditions including hypertension, dyslipidemia, diabetes, overweight, and obesity
practitioner_domains.specialization_notes: Most commonly treated conditions due to their prevalence and interconnected nature

constructs_mentioned.construct_description: Management of blood glucose levels across the spectrum of insulin resistance from normal to diabetic states
constructs_mentioned.why_important: Core metabolic function that affects overall health and chronic disease risk
constructs_mentioned.how_assessed: Hemoglobin A1C, fasting glucose, fasting insulin, HOMA-IR calculation, oral glucose tolerance tests

constructs_mentioned.construct_description: Spectrum from normal insulin sensitivity to severe insulin resistance requiring exogenous insulin
constructs_mentioned.why_important: Early detection and management prevents progression to diabetes and other complications
constructs_mentioned.how_assessed: HOMA-IR calculation, fasting insulin levels, oral glucose tolerance test (gold standard)

constructs_mentioned.construct_description: Assessment of body fat percentage, lean mass, and visceral adipose tissue distribution
constructs_mentioned.why_important: Better indicator of health risk than BMI alone, relates to chronic disease risk
constructs_mentioned.how_assessed: DEXA scan (gold standard), BMI, waist circumference, waist-to-hip ratio

constructs_mentioned.construct_description: Assessment of sleep disorders, sleep duration, sleep schedule regularity, and subjective sleep experience
constructs_mentioned.why_important: Critical for blood glucose management and overall metabolic health
constructs_mentioned.how_assessed: GSAQ questionnaire, Pittsburgh Sleep Quality Index, Stop-Bang assessment, subjective interviews, wearable data

constructs_mentioned.construct_description: Comprehensive evaluation of dietary patterns, eating behaviors, and nutritional quality
constructs_mentioned.why_important: Highest priority intervention for blood glucose management
constructs_mentioned.how_assessed: 24-hour dietary recalls, food logging, Diet ID tool, CGM data correlation, structured interviews

constructs_mentioned.construct_description: Evaluation of exercise patterns, daily activity levels, and movement behaviors
constructs_mentioned.why_important: Key intervention for metabolic health and insulin sensitivity
constructs_mentioned.how_assessed: IPAQ questionnaire, wearable data, structured interviews, steps tracking, intensity assessment

constructs_mentioned.construct_description: Assessment of stress levels, coping mechanisms, and stress-related health impacts
constructs_mentioned.why_important: Affects blood glucose management and overall metabolic function
constructs_mentioned.how_assessed: PSS-4 questionnaire, GAD-7, PHQ-9, subjective interviews, Oura Ring stress metrics

constructs_mentioned.construct_description: Comprehensive assessment of weight trajectory, previous interventions, and weight-related factors
constructs_mentioned.why_important: Critical context for interpreting body composition results and planning interventions
constructs_mentioned.how_assessed: Structured interviews about weight history, eating disorder screening, medication review

health_performance_factors.description: Three-month average blood glucose levels reflected in red blood cell glycation
health_performance_factors.measurement_approach: Blood test, non-fasting, PDF report with reference ranges

health_performance_factors.description: Amount of fat tissue around internal organs, age and ethnicity-adjusted ranges
health_performance_factors.measurement_approach: DEXA scan with standardized reference ranges

health_performance_factors.description: Risk assessment for obstructive sleep apnea based on clinical factors
health_performance_factors.measurement_approach: Stop-Bang questionnaire, clinical assessment, sleep study referral

health_performance_factors.description: Individual blood glucose response to food intake and daily activities
health_performance_factors.measurement_approach: Continuous glucose monitoring (Stilo/Dexcom) integrated with lifestyle data

health_performance_factors.description: Individual capacity for light, moderate, and vigorous physical activity
health_performance_factors.measurement_approach: RPE assessment, talk test, wearable heart rate data

health_performance_factors.description: Patterns of food consumption, meal timing, and eating habits
health_performance_factors.measurement_approach: 24-hour dietary recalls, food logging, structured interviews

health_performance_factors.description: Sleep schedule regularity, bedtime routines, and sleep environment factors
health_performance_factors.measurement_approach: Subjective interviews, sleep questionnaires, wearable sleep tracking

health_performance_factors.description: Individual capacity to manage demands relative to available resources
health_performance_factors.measurement_approach: PSS-4 questionnaire, structured interviews about coping strategies

interventions.intervention_description: Comprehensive lifestyle intervention leveraging six areas: nutrition, physical activity, sleep, stress management, substance use reduction, and positive social connection to prevent disease and treat existing conditions
interventions.purpose: Prevent disease, treat existing conditions, and optimize human functioning beyond disease management

dosage_details.intensity: Individualized based on patient needs and capabilities
dosage_details.progression: Gradual optimization of each pillar based on patient readiness and response

implementation_specifics.delivery_method: Structured interview and assessment followed by individualized intervention planning
implementation_specifics.monitoring_approach: Regular follow-up assessments and patient self-monitoring
implementation_specifics.adjustment_criteria: Based on patient goals, response, and changing circumstances

resource_requirements.expertise_required: Lifestyle medicine practitioner with expertise in chronic disease management

interventions.intervention_description: Detailed assessment and modification of eating patterns through structured dietary recalls and ongoing food journaling using various tools including apps, Excel sheets, or photo documentation
interventions.purpose: Understand current eating behaviors and implement targeted nutritional modifications for blood glucose management

dosage_details.frequency: Initial 24-hour recall, then ongoing food logging as needed
dosage_details.duration: Ongoing monitoring with periodic intensive logging periods
dosage_details.intensity: Detailed documentation of all food intake
dosage_details.progression: From detailed logging to sustainable eating pattern modifications

implementation_specifics.delivery_method: Patient self-documentation with clinician review and guidance
implementation_specifics.monitoring_approach: Review of food logs, apps, photos, or written documentation
implementation_specifics.adjustment_criteria: Based on blood glucose response and patient preferences

resource_requirements.time_commitment: Daily logging time plus periodic review sessions

interventions.intervention_name: Continuous Glucose Monitoring (CGM) with Lifestyle Integration
interventions.intervention_description: Use of CGM devices like Stilo (Dexcom partnership with Oura) to monitor blood glucose responses to meals, sleep, stress, and physical activity in real-time
interventions.purpose: Provide personalized glucose response data to optimize lifestyle interventions and increase patient awareness

dosage_details.duration: Typically used for specific assessment periods, not permanently
dosage_details.volume: Complete glucose data integrated with lifestyle factors
dosage_details.progression: From monitoring to behavior modification based on glucose patterns

implementation_specifics.delivery_method: Wearable patch sensor with smartphone app integration
implementation_specifics.monitoring_approach: Real-time glucose data with meal, sleep, and activity correlation
implementation_specifics.adjustment_criteria: Used in conjunction with clinician guidance for interpretation

resource_requirements.time_commitment: Minimal daily time for data review
resource_requirements.expertise_required: Clinician with blood glucose management expertise for interpretation

interventions.intervention_description: Structured approach to achieve 150 minutes/week moderate intensity or 75 minutes vigorous intensity physical activity plus 2 days strength training targeting all major muscle groups
interventions.purpose: Meet Physical Activity Guidelines for Americans to improve blood glucose management and overall health

dosage_details.frequency: 150 minutes moderate or 75 minutes vigorous per week, plus 2 strength training days
dosage_details.intensity: Moderate to vigorous based on individual capacity
dosage_details.volume: Specific weekly minute targets with strength training
dosage_details.progression: Gradual increase toward guidelines, then beyond if appropriate

implementation_specifics.delivery_method: Individualized exercise prescription based on current fitness level and preferences
implementation_specifics.monitoring_approach: IPAQ questionnaire and wearable device tracking
implementation_specifics.adjustment_criteria: Based on patient's baseline state, perceived exertion, and progress

equipment_needed: Access to exercise facilities or equipment
resource_requirements.time_commitment: 2.5-5 hours per week depending on intensity choice

interventions.intervention_description: Comprehensive sleep assessment and intervention including sleep disorder screening, sleep hygiene education, and targeting 7-9 hours of quality sleep for adults
interventions.purpose: Optimize sleep quality and quantity to improve blood glucose management and overall health

dosage_details.duration: 7-9 hours per night for general adult population
dosage_details.intensity: Focus on sleep quality and consistency
dosage_details.progression: From sleep assessment to disorder treatment to optimization

implementation_specifics.delivery_method: Sleep questionnaires, sleep studies if needed, sleep hygiene counseling
implementation_specifics.monitoring_approach: Sleep questionnaires (GSAQ, Pittsburgh Sleep Quality Index), wearable sleep tracking
implementation_specifics.adjustment_criteria: Based on sleep study results, questionnaire scores, and subjective sleep quality reports

resource_requirements.time_commitment: 7-9 hours nightly plus time for sleep hygiene practices
resource_requirements.expertise_required: Sleep medicine knowledge, potential sleep specialist referral
resource_requirements.cost_level: Low to High depending on sleep study needs

interventions.intervention_name: Stress Management and Mental Health Assessment Protocol
interventions.intervention_description: Comprehensive stress assessment using validated tools (PSS4, GAD-7, PHQ-9) followed by individualized stress management interventions based on patient's resources and demands
interventions.purpose: Identify and manage stress levels to improve blood glucose management and overall health outcomes

dosage_details.frequency: Ongoing stress management practices with periodic assessment
dosage_details.intensity: Individualized based on stress levels and coping resources
dosage_details.volume: Comprehensive stress assessment and management approach
dosage_details.progression: From assessment to skill building to maintenance

implementation_specifics.delivery_method: Validated questionnaires, clinical interviews, stress management education
implementation_specifics.monitoring_approach: PSS4 trending over time, Oura Ring stress metrics, subjective reporting
implementation_specifics.adjustment_criteria: Based on questionnaire scores, life circumstances, and patient response

resource_requirements.time_commitment: Regular practice of stress management techniques
resource_requirements.expertise_required: Mental health assessment skills, stress management intervention knowledge

interventions.intervention_description: Comprehensive weight management approach that considers patient's weight history, previous attempts, eating disorder screening, and medical factors affecting weight
interventions.purpose: Develop sustainable weight management strategies based on individual history and circumstances

dosage_details.frequency: Ongoing weight management with regular monitoring
dosage_details.intensity: Individualized based on weight history and goals
dosage_details.volume: Comprehensive approach considering all weight-affecting factors
dosage_details.progression: Gradual, sustainable changes based on patient's weight journey

implementation_specifics.delivery_method: Detailed weight history interview, eating disorder screening, medical assessment
implementation_specifics.monitoring_approach: Regular weight tracking, body composition monitoring, progress assessment
implementation_specifics.adjustment_criteria: Based on weight trajectory, life circumstances, and medical factors

resource_requirements.time_commitment: Regular monitoring and lifestyle modification time
resource_requirements.expertise_required: Weight management expertise, eating disorder awareness

construct_relationships.relationship_description: Insulin resistance exists on a spectrum from normal glycemic control to impaired glucose tolerance, pre-diabetes, and frank type 2 diabetes
construct_relationships.evidence_mentioned: Mollie describes metabolic health as blood glucose management with insulin resistance as the underlying spectrum

construct_relationships.relationship_description: Body composition, particularly visceral adipose tissue and BMI, correlates with insulin resistance and metabolic syndrome
construct_relationships.evidence_mentioned: Mollie mentions looking at body composition as part of cardiometabolic assessment and its relationship to diabetes risk

construct_relationships.relationship_description: Sleep disorders, particularly sleep apnea, and poor sleep quality directly impact blood glucose management
construct_relationships.evidence_mentioned: Mollie identifies sleep as one of the four highest priority pillars for blood glucose management

construct_relationships.relationship_description: Stress levels and stress management capabilities directly influence blood glucose control
construct_relationships.evidence_mentioned: Stress is identified as one of the four most impactful pillars for blood glucose management

construct_relationships.relationship_description: Physical activity levels and exercise patterns directly impact glucose metabolism and insulin sensitivity
construct_relationships.evidence_mentioned: Physical activity is one of the four highest priority pillars for blood glucose management

construct_relationships.relationship_description: Dietary patterns, meal timing, and food choices directly affect blood glucose excursions and long-term glucose management
construct_relationships.evidence_mentioned: Nutrition is identified as the most impactful pillar for blood glucose management

construct_relationships.relationship_description: Weight history provides critical context for interpreting current body composition measurements
construct_relationships.evidence_mentioned: Mollie emphasizes that weight history is critical for interpreting body composition results - someone who lost 100 pounds with BMI 35 is very different from someone gaining weight

intervention_construct_links.mechanism_of_action: Comprehensive optimization of nutrition, physical activity, sleep, stress reduction, substance use reduction, and social connection to address root causes
intervention_construct_links.timeline_expectations: Variable depending on pillar - some immediate effects, others require sustained practice over months

intervention_construct_links.intervention_name: Continuous Glucose Monitoring (CGM) with Lifestyle Integration
intervention_construct_links.mechanism_of_action: Real-time glucose monitoring integrated with meal logging, sleep, stress, and activity data to provide personalized feedback
intervention_construct_links.timeline_expectations: Immediate feedback during 2-week sensor wear period

intervention_construct_links.mechanism_of_action: Address sleep disorders, improve sleep hygiene, optimize sleep duration and timing
intervention_construct_links.timeline_expectations: Sleep study results in weeks, sleep hygiene improvements in days to weeks

intervention_construct_links.mechanism_of_action: Personalized approach based on individual weight trajectory, previous attempts, and current context
intervention_construct_links.timeline_expectations: Long-term approach over months to years with regular monitoring

assessment_intervention_connections.intervention_name: Continuous Glucose Monitoring (CGM) with Lifestyle Integration

assessment_intervention_connections.intervention_name: Stress Management and Mental Health Assessment Protocol

IPAQ results inform personalized physical activity recommendations based on current activity levels and 150-minute weekly target

mentioned_advantages: Gold standard for determining body composition

Shows personal glucose response to meals

what_it_measures: Dietary patterns using Healthy Eating Index

metrics.normal_ranges: 5.6% and below normal, 5.7-6.4% pre-diabetes, 6.5% and above diabetes
metrics.interpretation_notes: Three months average blood sugar, lagging indicator of insulin resistance
metrics.reliability_notes: High confidence but must look at whole person context

metrics.interpretation_notes: Must be collected fasting
Must be collected fasting, used for HOMA-IR calculation

metrics.assessment_source: Calculated from fasting insulin and glucose
metrics.normal_ranges: Less than 2 indicates no signs of insulin resistance
metrics.interpretation_notes: Can detect earlier insulin resistance than A1C
Calculated from height and weight
metrics.reliability_notes: Lowest confidence among body composition measures

metrics.assessment_source: DEXA scan or other body composition methods
metrics.interpretation_notes: DEXA is gold standard
metrics.reliability_notes: Highest confidence when measured by DEXA

metrics.interpretation_notes: Must be measured at appropriate body landmarks
Requires measurement at appropriate landmarks

metrics.normal_ranges: Age, sex, and ethnicity adjusted ranges
metrics.interpretation_notes: Less is better, associated with chronic disease risk
Used primarily for self-monitoring and awareness
Assesses sleep apnea risk
metrics.reliability_notes: High confidence for sleep apnea screening

metrics.interpretation_notes: Can be trended over time

metrics.normal_ranges: 150 minutes moderate intensity or 75 minutes vigorous intensity per week
metrics.interpretation_notes: Based on Physical Activity Guidelines for Americans
Correlates with improved health outcomes

timing_considerations: Interstitial fluid vs blood glucose timing differences

specific_values_mentioned: Higher prevalence in men and people with obesity

timing_considerations: All major muscle groups for strength training

client_goals.goal_description: Optimal health and functioning through lifestyle medicine
Prevention and treatment of cardiometabolic conditions
Weight management goals based on individual journey

constraints_preferences.description: Limited vs moderate vs unlimited resources affecting assessment depth
constraints_preferences.impact_on_assessment: Determines which tests can be performed (basic BMI/A1C vs DEXA/fasting insulin vs oral glucose tolerance test)
constraints_preferences.impact_on_intervention: Affects comprehensiveness of lifestyle assessment and follow-up monitoring

constraints_preferences.description: Oral glucose tolerance test requires 3 hours at testing facility
Not all labs offer oral glucose tolerance testing
constraints_preferences.impact_on_assessment: Limited availability of gold standard insulin resistance testing
workaround_strategies: Refer to specialized facilities when necessary

constraints_preferences.description: Patient food logging preferences and technology comfort
constraints_preferences.impact_on_assessment: Affects quality and consistency of nutritional data collection
constraints_preferences.impact_on_intervention: Must accommodate individual preferences for sustainable monitoring
workaround_strategies: Accept any format (Excel, Word, apps, photos)
Use AI-powered tools like Aura Stilo

moderating_factors.factor_name: Medical conditions affecting red blood cells
moderating_factors.description: Iron deficiency, sickle cell anemia, hemoglobinopathies
moderating_factors.management_approach: Consider alternative glucose monitoring methods, interpret A1C with caution

moderating_factors.description: Oral steroids, antipsychotics, gabapentin, lyrica affecting weight and glucose
moderating_factors.what_it_affects: Blood glucose levels and weight management outcomes
moderating_factors.management_approach: Account for medication effects in interpretation, provide appropriate counseling

moderating_factors.description: Travel, stress, seasonal changes, life events
moderating_factors.management_approach: Contextualize results within life circumstances, adjust expectations and interventions

moderating_factors.description: Previous weight loss/gain patterns, current trajectory
moderating_factors.what_it_affects: Interpretation of body composition results and goal setting
moderating_factors.management_approach: Understand individual weight journey, set realistic expectations, celebrate appropriate wins

moderating_factors.description: Sleep apnea, insomnia, circadian rhythm disorders
moderating_factors.what_it_affects: Blood glucose management and overall health outcomes
moderating_factors.management_approach: Screen with validated tools, refer for sleep studies when indicated

moderating_factors.what_it_affects: Stress assessment accuracy and intervention approaches
moderating_factors.management_approach: Screen with GAD-7, PHQ-9, ensure appropriate resources before addressing trauma

individual_differences.intervention_implications: May need specialized treatment approaches, avoid certain interventions

implementation_steps: Conduct comprehensive assessment across all six pillars (nutrition, physical activity, sleep, stress management, substance use reduction, positive social connection)
Prioritize pillars based on health condition - for blood glucose management focus on nutrition, physical activity, sleep, and stress as highest priority
Use evidence-based protocols blending conventional western medicine with lifestyle interventions
Develop individualized optimization plan targeting each relevant pillar
Implement interventions progressively rather than simultaneously to ensure sustainability
Regular monitoring and adjustment of interventions based on patient response

dosage_specifications.specific_parameters: Individualized based on patient's current state, medical history, and goals
dosage_specifications.progression_rules: Start with foundational elements, progress based on patient adherence and response
dosage_specifications.modification_criteria: Adjust based on patient feedback, objective measures, and life circumstances

monitoring_protocols: Regular follow-up assessments using same tools as initial evaluation
Track objective measures (lab values, anthropometric data, wearable data)
Monitor subjective reports of energy, sleep quality, stress levels
Assess adherence to lifestyle modifications
safety_considerations: Screen for eating disorders before implementing nutrition interventions
Consider medication interactions with lifestyle changes
Monitor for contraindications based on medical history
Ensure appropriate referrals when interventions exceed scope of practice

implementation_steps: Conduct structured interview asking patient to recall everything consumed in previous 24 hours
Ask clarifying questions about portion sizes, preparation methods, timing of meals
Determine if recalled day was typical or atypical for patient's usual eating pattern
Assess eating patterns: frequency of meals, snacking habits, regularity of eating schedule
Evaluate food sourcing: cooking vs eating out vs prepared foods
Implement ongoing food logging using patient's preferred method (app, written log, photos)
Review food logs regularly and provide feedback on patterns and opportunities for improvement

dosage_specifications.specific_parameters: Initial 24-hour recall, followed by ongoing logging frequency determined by patient capacity and goals
dosage_specifications.progression_rules: Start with simple logging, progress to more detailed tracking as patient becomes comfortable
dosage_specifications.modification_criteria: Adjust logging method and frequency based on patient preferences and adherence

monitoring_protocols: Regular review of food logs during follow-up appointments
Track changes in eating patterns over time
Monitor correlation between dietary changes and health outcomes
Use tools like Aura Stilo food logging or Diet ID for enhanced tracking when available
safety_considerations: Screen for eating disorders before implementing detailed food tracking
Avoid creating obsessive behaviors around food logging
Ensure food logging supports rather than hinders healthy relationship with food
Consider patient's mental health status when implementing tracking protocols

intervention_protocols.intervention_name: Continuous Glucose Monitoring (CGM) with Lifestyle Integration
implementation_steps: Determine appropriate candidates for CGM use (not recommended for all patients)
Provide education on CGM function, limitations, and interpretation
Apply CGM sensor (typically on tricep area) for 2-week monitoring period
Integrate CGM data with lifestyle factors (meals, exercise, sleep, stress)
Use platforms like Stilo/Aura integration to correlate glucose with other health metrics
Provide ongoing interpretation and contextualization of glucose excursions
Help patient understand normal physiologic glucose responses vs concerning patterns

dosage_specifications.specific_parameters: 2-week sensor wear periods, frequency determined by clinical need and patient goals
dosage_specifications.progression_rules: Initial monitoring period with intensive education, followed by periodic monitoring as needed
dosage_specifications.modification_criteria: Adjust frequency based on patient's glucose management progress and learning needs

monitoring_protocols: Daily review of glucose patterns in context of lifestyle factors
Weekly analysis of trends and patterns
Correlation with other health metrics (sleep, stress, activity)
Regular check-ins to ensure proper interpretation of data
safety_considerations: Ensure patient understands CGM data is not 100% accurate (within 20% of blood glucose)
Provide clear guidelines on when to seek medical attention
Avoid creating anxiety about normal glucose fluctuations
Ensure proper sensor application and skin care
Not recommended for insulin-dependent diabetes without additional safeguards

implementation_steps: Assess current activity level using IPAQ questionnaire and patient interview
Establish baseline understanding of light, moderate, and vigorous intensity activities
Set goals based on Physical Activity Guidelines for Americans: 150 minutes moderate intensity or 75 minutes vigorous intensity per week, plus 2 days strength training
Develop individualized activity plan considering patient preferences, access, and current fitness level
Distinguish between structured exercise and daily physical activity/steps
Implement progressive activity increases to avoid injury and promote adherence
Integrate wearable technology when available for objective activity tracking

dosage_specifications.specific_parameters: Target: 150 min/week moderate intensity OR 75 min/week vigorous intensity PLUS 2 days/week strength training all major muscle groups
dosage_specifications.progression_rules: Start below current capacity, increase by 10-20% weekly as tolerated
dosage_specifications.modification_criteria: Adjust intensity and duration based on patient's baseline fitness, medical conditions, and response to activity

monitoring_protocols: Weekly activity logs or wearable data review
Monitor perceived exertion using talk test or RPE scale
Track daily steps when possible
Assess adherence and barriers during regular follow-ups
Monitor for signs of overexertion or injury
safety_considerations: Consider baseline health status and medical clearance needs
Start conservatively and progress gradually
Monitor for signs of overexertion
Adjust recommendations for individuals with cardiovascular or musculoskeletal conditions
Ensure proper form and technique instruction for strength training

implementation_steps: Conduct comprehensive sleep assessment using GSAQ (General Sleep Assessment Questionnaire)
Screen for sleep disorders using appropriate tools (STOP-BANG for sleep apnea, ISI for insomnia)
Assess sleep quantity (7-9 hours for general adult population), quality, and regularity
Evaluate sleep hygiene practices and environmental factors
Address identified sleep disorders through appropriate referrals when necessary
Implement sleep hygiene education and behavioral modifications
Monitor sleep patterns using wearables when available (primarily for sleep duration tracking)
Coordinate with sleep medicine specialists for complex cases requiring sleep studies

dosage_specifications.specific_parameters: Target 7-9 hours nightly sleep with consistent sleep/wake times
dosage_specifications.progression_rules: Implement sleep hygiene changes gradually, address most impactful factors first
dosage_specifications.modification_criteria: Adjust recommendations based on work schedules, family obligations, and individual sleep needs

monitoring_protocols: Weekly sleep logs or wearable sleep data review
Monitor subjective sleep quality and daytime energy levels
Track sleep duration and consistency
Follow up on sleep study results and specialist recommendations
Assess impact of sleep improvements on other health metrics
safety_considerations: Screen for serious sleep disorders requiring medical intervention
Refer for sleep studies when indicated by assessment tools
Consider medication effects on sleep
Monitor for signs of sleep deprivation affecting daily functioning
Coordinate care with other healthcare providers for complex sleep disorders

intervention_protocols.intervention_name: Stress Management and Mental Health Assessment Protocol
implementation_steps: Conduct mental health screening using GAD-7 (anxiety) and PHQ-9 (depression)
Assess stress using PSS-4 (Perceived Stress Scale) and clinical interview
Evaluate demands vs. resources framework to understand stress sources
Screen for trauma history when appropriate resources available for follow-up
Assess current stress management techniques and their effectiveness
Implement stress reduction interventions based on individual needs and preferences
Integrate wearable stress metrics when available (e.g., Aura Ring) as supplementary data
Coordinate with mental health professionals when indicated

dosage_specifications.specific_parameters: Individualized based on stress level assessment and patient capacity
dosage_specifications.progression_rules: Start with simple, accessible stress management techniques, build complexity over time
dosage_specifications.modification_criteria: Adjust interventions based on patient response, life circumstances, and mental health status

monitoring_protocols: Regular PSS-4 administration to track stress levels over time
Monitor subjective reports of stress and coping effectiveness
Track wearable stress metrics when available
Assess correlation between stress management and other health outcomes
Monitor for signs of worsening mental health requiring professional intervention
safety_considerations: Screen for serious mental health conditions requiring professional treatment
Avoid diving into trauma history without appropriate resources and training
Recognize scope of practice limitations regarding mental health interventions
Maintain appropriate referral relationships with mental health professionals
Monitor for substance use as maladaptive stress management

implementation_steps: Conduct comprehensive weight history assessment including highest/lowest weights, weight trajectory, and previous weight loss/gain attempts
Screen for eating disorders (restrictive and binge eating disorders)
Assess medical conditions and medications affecting weight
Evaluate patient's relationship with weight and food
Understand family history and cultural factors affecting weight
Develop weight management plan informed by patient's history and current context
Set realistic goals based on patient's weight journey and maintenance capacity
Address underlying factors contributing to weight challenges

dosage_specifications.specific_parameters: Individualized based on patient's weight history, current status, and realistic maintenance capacity
dosage_specifications.progression_rules: Focus on sustainable changes rather than rapid weight loss, consider patient's previous successful strategies
dosage_specifications.modification_criteria: Adjust goals and interventions based on patient's weight history patterns and current life circumstances

monitoring_protocols: Regular weight and body composition tracking
Monitor trends over time rather than focusing on individual measurements
Assess adherence to lifestyle modifications
Track correlation between weight changes and other health metrics
Monitor for signs of disordered eating behaviors
safety_considerations: Screen for and avoid triggering eating disorders
Recognize that weight regain is common and plan accordingly
Focus on health improvements beyond weight loss
Consider psychological impact of weight management interventions
Coordinate with eating disorder specialists when indicated

practical_considerations.description: Different levels of available resources affect assessment and intervention options
practical_solutions: Low resource: Focus on basic assessments (weight, BMI, A1C, lifestyle questionnaire)
Moderate resource: Add fasting insulin, DEXA scan, detailed lifestyle interviews
High resource: Include oral glucose tolerance test, comprehensive wearable integration, specialized referrals

practical_considerations.description: Interventions must be tailored to patient preferences and capacity for sustainable implementation
practical_solutions: Start with patient-preferred methods and tools
Implement changes gradually rather than simultaneously
Regular check-ins to assess barriers and modify approaches
Focus on sustainable long-term changes rather than intensive short-term interventions

practical_considerations.description: Wearables and apps can enhance monitoring but require proper interpretation and patient education
practical_solutions: Provide education on limitations and proper interpretation of wearable data
Use technology as supplementary rather than primary assessment tool
Choose user-friendly platforms that match patient's technical comfort level
Integrate multiple data sources for comprehensive picture

practical_considerations.description: Recognition of when to refer to specialists vs. manage within lifestyle medicine practice
practical_solutions: Maintain clear referral criteria for sleep studies, mental health, eating disorders
Establish relationships with specialists for coordinated care
Focus on lifestyle interventions while coordinating with medical management
Regular assessment of when patient needs exceed current scope

recommendations.description: Add core lifestyle medicine constructs and the six pillars as foundational entities in the ontology
Establish hierarchical relationships between lifestyle medicine and its six component areas (nutrition, physical activity, sleep, stress management, substance use reduction, social connection)
Expand cardiometabolic disease entities to include the specific conditions mentioned (hypertension, dyslipidemia, diabetes, obesity)
Validate the relationship between lifestyle interventions and both disease prevention and treatment of existing conditions
Clarify terminology around 'cardioabolic' vs 'cardiometabolic' conditions for consistency
